docs.lead_paragraph: Even as critical features of the landmark health care legislation of March 2010 are being put into place, the battle over reform rages on. House Republicans, whose unified vote for repeal was blocked by Senate Democrats, would now like to bar spending on the law. Meanwhile, President Obama, in a recent speech to the Chamber of Commerce, reminded business executives that ''we could not accept a broken system where insurance companies could drop people because they got sick, or families went bankrupt because of medical bills.'' And of course, the legal challenges continue to wend their way toward the Supreme Court. Health reform, in short, is very much a work in progress. This report--the second in a series--examines that progress on three key dimensions: Roll-Out (Are milestones being met?), Reactions (Are key players cooperating?) and Results (is reform controlling costs of covering Americans?).
docs.abstract: Prof Jacob S Hacker and Carl DeTorres Op-Chart, second in series, examines progress on three key dimensions of health care reform--Roll-Out, Reactions and Results; assigns overall grade of 'B' to current effort to put key features of law into place (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Update: People: this isn't my chart, it's the government's, as you would see if you clicked on the link. And the pie on the right adds up to 71 percent because, as the figure clearly shows, insurance accounts for 71% of total spending. Before you complain about a post, try reading it first.

Getting employees to focus on their health can be challenging in the best of times, but may be even harder during tough economic times, according to Towers Watson, a consulting firm that advises employers on health benefits.
docs.abstract: A survey of 3,000 employees found there had been a significant decrease in workers' focus on their own health in the last two years.
